availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.24 (7 June-14 June 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 24. Mercurius Publicus: COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence, WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order of the Council of State. From Thur≈øday June 7. to Thur≈øday June 14. 1660.

div.p: THis day the Petition of divers Lords, Knights Gentlemen, of the ≈øix Counties of Northwales, (from whence during all the time of the late U≈øurpation of the Government, no publique Addre≈øs or Petition was ever made) was pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty by the Noble Lord, the Lord Vi≈øcount Bulkley, accompnied by the per≈øons who ≈øub≈øcribed the ≈øame; which Petition was as followeth:

div.head: To the KINGS mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty.
The humble Petition of divers Lords, Knights, and Gentlemen, Inhabitants of the ≈øix Counties of Northwales, who≈øe names are ≈øub≈øcribed,
div.p: THat your Petitioners during the Vici≈ø≈øitudes of eighteen years troubles, having ≈øuffered as much and repined as little as any part of your ≈øaid Maje≈øties Realm have done, do now e≈øteem it the glory of their fir≈øt publick Addre≈øs that it is to your Maje≈øty the mo≈øt Gracious of Princes.

Exce≈øs of joy hath oft ≈øtruck men dumbe; but we who now carry our hearts in our mouthes, may as well live and not breathe, as not profe≈øs our ≈øelves enlivened by your Maje≈øties return unto us: That having bin the end of our con≈øtant prayers, is now the fruition of tho≈øe longing hopes which rendered our ≈øufferings tollerable, and pre≈øerved us to this time to pray for your Maje≈øties long and happy Raign.

And as your Maje≈øtie hath attained the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of your Crowns, by the glorious conque≈øt of an Heroick patience, ≈øo ≈øhall we humbly endeavour to follow your Princely example, by ≈øo far di≈øowning all (even ju≈øt) Animo≈øities as ≈øhall we hope in a peculiar ≈øence render us your Maje≈øties mo≈øt obedient ≈øubjects.

Yet we deny our ≈øelves the lea≈øt har≈øh or revengefull thought for tho≈øe Oppre≈ø≈øions we ≈øo long and ≈øignally have layn under, we are not able to dige≈øt the dete≈øtable and horrid murther of your Royal Father, our once mo≈øt Gracious Soveraign, in averting the guilt of who≈øe blood all are concerned, who have no mind to draw it upon them≈øelves.

p.hi:
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray, That not onely ≈øuch
of tho≈øe principally engaged in that execrable murther, as to your Maje≈øty and the honourable Parliament ≈øhall ≈øeem me ‚Ä¢ s, be forth with delivered over to publick Ju≈øtice: But that al≈øo ≈øuch others as concurred therein, or procured and prom ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ etitions to bring on that horrid Tryal, or other Addre≈ø≈øes to own the ≈øame (and have not ≈øince given early te≈øtimony of their unforced repentance) may be diligently taken notice of, and di≈øabled to bear any office of tru≈øt Civil or Military in your Maje≈øties Realme, that ≈øo the lives of your Maje≈øties mo≈øt loyal ≈øubjects may no more come into the cruel hands of Blood thirsty men.

closer.signed:
Lord Powys, Lord Herbert, Lord Bulkley, Sir Thomas Hammer, Sir Jo. Salisbury, Thomas Bulkeley E≈øq William Herbert E≈øq Sir Evan Lloyd, Sir John Owen, Sir Roger Mostyn, Sir John Carter, Iohn Hammer, Richard Wyn, Iohn Bodvell, Will. Griffith, Nicholas Bagnol E≈øquires, Iohn Middleton, Iohn Nanney, Will. Hampheries, Richard Broughton, Col. Rich. Lloyd, Will. Raven≈øcroft, William Glynn, Henry B ‚Ä¢ lkley, Col. Hugh Wynn, Hen. Conway, Piers Lloyd, Robert Williams, Eubale Thetwal, Tho. Crachley, Sir Charles Lloyd, Robert Davies junior, Col. Roger Mo≈øtyn, Will. Bold, Edmund Metrick, Lewis Lloyd, Tho. Grave≈ønor, Ph ‚Ä¢ l. Egerton, Col. Tho. Raven≈øcroft, Robert Whitley, Griff. Bodurda, Edward Bereton, Iohn Do ‚Ä¢ ben, Evan Vaughan, Robert Broughton, Rich. Middleton, Hugh Roberts, Rich. Wynn, Ken. Eaton, Nic. Bayly, Hen. Iones, John Price, Hugh Pennant, Francis Manley, Will. Hill, Edward Price, Col. Io. Robin≈øon, Hugh Bodurda, Will. Williams, Owen Hughes, Robert Price, Hugh Maurice, Iohn Lloyd, Tho. Weave, Will, Par ‚Ä¢ y, Tho. Wynn, Iohn Williams, Oliver Broughton E≈øquires, Tho. Baker, Iohn Llyod, Tho. VVilliams, Hugh VVilliams, Arthur Trevor, Col. Roger VVhitley, Iohn Parry, Trevor Lloyd, Edward Pennant, Tho. Vaughan, Io. Griffith, Col. Fran. Trafford, Lewis, Lewis, Iohn Lloyd, VVill. Humphreys, Hugh Meredith, Robert Challenor, Price Devereux, Somer≈øet Fox, Maurice Piges, Richard
Hughes, Anthony Challonor, Richard Price, VVilliam Vaughan, Geo. R ‚Ä¢ ven≈øcroft, Trevor Lloyd, VVill. Iones, Robert Griffeth E≈øquires.

div.p: The Petition being pre≈øented as afore≈øaid, his Maje≈øty was G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iou≈øly plea≈øed to tell the Petitioners. That he was ≈øufficiently ≈øatisfied of their loyalty to the King his Father, and ≈øen≈øible of their ≈øufferings for him And was al≈øo plea≈øed to a≈ø≈øure them of his ≈øpecial Grace and Favour.

div.head: VVhitehall.
div.p: On Wedne≈øday the ≈øixth in≈øtant, the B ‚Ä¢ liffs, Burge≈ø≈øes, and commonalty of the Town of Ip≈øwich, accompanied by M. Sicklem ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ , Captain Sparrow, Mr. Keen, and divers other Gentlemen, attended his Maje≈øty, and pre≈øented him with ≈øix hundred pieces of gold from the Town of Ip≈øwich, which his Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to accept.

The ≈øame day the Earl of Cleaveland brought about two hundred Gentlemen, many of them Officers formerly ≈øerving under him, the others Gentlemen that rid in his troop to meet his Maje≈øty to ki≈øs his Maje≈øties hand, who kneeling down in the m ‚Ä¢ tted Gallery, his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to walk along, and give every one of them the honour to ki≈øs his hand, which favour was ≈øo highly re≈øented by them that they could no longer ≈øtifle their joy, but as his Maje≈øty was walking out (a thing, though unu≈øual at Court) they brake out into a loud ≈øhouting.

On Thur≈øday Mr. VVall ‚Ä¢ p, the Deputy, Steward and Burge≈ø≈øes of the City of We≈øtmin≈øter in their Gowns, being conducted by Mr. Gerard, a member of Parliament for that City, waited upon his Maje≈øty, and pre≈øented a Petition, wherein they de≈øired that his Maje≈øty would be graciou≈øly plea≈øed to be≈øtow the Office of Lord High Steward of We≈øtmin≈øter on his Excellency the Lord General Monck M. Gerard made a ≈øhort ≈øpeech to his Maje≈øty, leaving it to the Steward to inlarge, who delivered him≈øelf ≈øo rhetorically, and with ≈øuch due and awful re≈øpect to Maje≈øty, that he hath de≈øervedly gained a very high reputation in the Court, his Maje≈øty returned a mo≈øt gracious an≈øwer, and afforded to a ‚Ä¢ l of them the honour to ki≈øs his hand.

This day was publi≈øhed a Proclamation by his Maje≈øty, to ≈øummon the per≈øons therein named, who ≈øate, gave Judgement, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted in that horrid and dete≈øtable murder of his Maje≈øties Royal Father of ble≈ø≈øed memory, to appear and render them≈øelves within fourteen dayes after the publi≈øhing of that his Maje≈øties Royal Proclamation, to the Speaker or Speakers of the Hou≈øe of Peers or Commons, the Lord Mayor of the City of London, or the Sheriffs of the re≈øpective Counties of England or Wales, and that no per≈øon harbour or conceal them, under mi≈øpri≈øion of Trea≈øon.
The Per≈øons Names are:

Iohn Li≈øle, William Say, E≈øquires, Sir Hardre≈ø≈øe Waller, Valentine Wauton, Edward Whalley, E≈øqs; Sir Iohn Bourchier Knight, William Heveningham E≈øq I≈øaac Pennington Alderman of London, Henry Martin, Iohn Bark≈øtead, Gilbert Millington, Edmund Ludl ‚Ä¢ w, Iohn Hutchin≈øon, E≈øquires; Sir Michael Live≈øay Ba ‚Ä¢ onet, Robert Tichbourn, Owen Roe, Robert Lilburn, Aaria ‚Ä¢ Scro ‚Ä¢ pe, Iohn Okey, Iohn Hew≈øon, William Goffe, Cornelius Holland, Iohn Carew, Miles Corbet, Henry Smith, Thomas Wogan, Edmund Harvey, Thomas Scot, William Cawley, Iohn Downs, Nicholas Love, Vincent Potter, Augu≈øtine Garland, Iohn Dixw ‚Ä¢ l, George Fleetwood, Simon Meyne, Iames Temple, Peter Temple, Daniel Blagrave, Thomas Wait, E≈øquires.

To which are added the≈øe other per≈øons, as being al≈øo deeply guilty of that mo≈øt dete≈øtable and bloudy Trea≈øon, viz. Iohn Cook, employed as Solicitor; Andrew Broughton and Iohn Phelos, employed as Clerks; and Edward Dendy, who attended as Serjeant at Arms.

This day the Right Honourable the Lord Vi≈øcount Faulkland, (one of the Citizens in Parliament for the City of Oxon) did pre≈øent to his ≈øacred Maje≈øty the loyal and dutiful affections of that antient City, which they have alwayes borne to his Maje≈øty, and al≈øo to his late royal Father, and in particular did pre≈øent an In≈øtrument under the common ≈øeal of the ≈øaid City, whereby they did mo≈øt cheerfully undertake for ever hereafter to pay to his Maje≈øty the antient ≈øee-farm rent due from the ≈øaid City, which they were nece≈ø≈øitated to purcha≈øe from the late u≈øurped powers, for a con≈øiderable ≈øum of money; all which his Maje≈øty did mo≈øt graciou≈øly accept from them, and did then vouch≈øafe the honor to the Mayor, and divers worthy members of that City there pre≈øent, to ki≈øs his Royal hand, graciou≈øly declaring that he would alwayes vouch≈øafe his particular grace, favour, and protection to that antient and loyal City.

The ≈øame night his Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to honour the General with his company at Supper at the Cock-pit; before ≈øupper he conferred the honour of Knighthood on Colonel John Clobery, who had de≈øerved ≈øo well in his con≈øtant adhering to his Excellency, and prudent mannagement of affairs for the happy re≈øtoring of his Maje≈øty to his people. After ≈øupper, his Excellency entertained his Maje≈øty with ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Mu≈øick.

On Friday his Maje≈øty went to Hampton-Court, about five in the morning, returned about eleven, and then touch'd many that had been troubled with the Evil. At three of the clock in the afternoon, his Maje≈øty gave a meeting to the Parliament in the Banqueting-hou≈øe, and having heard Mr. Speaker, returned a mo≈øt gracious An≈øwer. His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to ≈øup this night with the Lord Cambden at Ken≈øington.

On Saturday the Knights of the ≈øhire for Sommer≈øet, a County that have ≈øufficiently manife≈øted their con≈øtant loyalty to his ≈øacred Maje≈øty, as well by their early actings of late (giving pre≈øidents to others to do tho≈øe things that tended to the bringing in of his Maje≈øty) as their former fidelity, delivered a Petition ≈øub≈øcribed by many of the Nobility and Gentry of that County to his Maje≈øty, wherein after they had expre≈ø≈øed their hearty joy for the happy re≈øtoration of his Maje≈øty, they humbly de≈øired that his Maje≈øty would be plea≈øed to take care for the ≈øetling of the Church, in ≈øuch manner as it was in the time of his Royal Grandfather and Father of ever ble≈ø≈øed memory.

div.head: At the Generals Quarters at the Cockpit.
div.p: Several Addre≈ø≈øes from ≈øeveral Regiments of the Army to his Maje≈øty, expre≈ø≈øing their great joy for his Maje≈øties happy re≈øtoration, and an a≈ø≈øurance of their loyalty were early delivered to his Excellency, though formerly forgot to be mentioned, viz. his Excellencies own Regiment of foot, Col. Fairfax his Regiment, and the Iri≈øh Brigades.

On Friday night his Excellency pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty the addre≈ø≈øes of the Regiments in Scotland, viz. that of Col. Morgans Regiment of hor≈øe, and ≈øub≈øcribed al≈øo by the Judges Commi≈ø≈øioners of Exci≈øe and Cu≈øtomes, and mo≈øt of the con≈øiderable civil officers, Col. Daniels Regiment, Col. Clarks, Col. Hughs and Co. Miles Man's.

The Commi≈ø≈øioners from Ireland, viz. Sir John Clotwerthy, Sir John King, Major A≈øton, and Major Rawden, who were here ≈øome time ≈øince, the Lord Broghil, Sir Paul Davies, Sir James Barry, Sir Thco. Jones, Sir Morris Eu≈øtace, Arthur Hill, Audley Merrin, and Rich. Kennady E≈øq lately come, will ≈øuddenly make addre≈øs to his Maje≈øty, having brought with them bills for the twenty thou≈øand pound for his Maje≈øty, and ≈øuch other ≈øums as the Convention ordered. Sir Charles Co ‚Ä¢ t cannot yet be „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øpared, though cho≈øen one of the Commi≈ø≈øioners, there having been lately ‚Ä¢ ome li ‚Ä¢ de c ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈øt in Ireland, which his pre≈øence will ea≈øily awe.

Dunkirk, June 1. The Offend Pyrates do dolly ≈ønap ≈ø ‚Ä¢ me of the Engli≈øh Ve≈ø≈øele ‚Ä¢ an hou≈øe was unhappily blown up with three barrels of Gunpowder, occa≈øioned by making of fire-works, but one child killed.

Edinburgh. Major Aberin, that was Deputy Governour of Edinborough Ca≈øtle, when Cromwell went into Scotland in 1656. lately hang'd him≈øelf, Tho. VViclch walking upon the Peer at Leith was threwn into the Sea.
The Covenant is very much pre≈ø≈øed in all parts, and great hopes they have of enjoying their former freedom. London.

Ellis and Puckle that conveyed away Miles Corbit, taken at Y ‚Ä¢ rmou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and one Par≈øon Titham at Coche≈øter, were brought to London on Saturday, and remain in the cu≈øtody of the Serjeant at Arms.
The Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Common-Council have taken the oath of Allegrance and Supremacy.
The Ea≈øt-India Company have he ≈øpake plate to the value of 3000 l. to be pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty.

A Spirit was lately apprehended and carried to the Guard at the Tower, for drawing away ≈øouldiers, whom after he had debauched, he put into ≈øhips to be tran≈øported, but after four dai ‚Ä¢ s impri≈øonment he was relea≈øed.

div.head: Thur≈øday June 5. At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: The Hou≈øe re≈øumed the debate concerning the Act of Oblivion and Indempnity, and re≈øolved, that Andrew Broughton, John Cook, and Edward Dendy, being per≈øons deeply guilty of the murther of the late Kings Maje≈øty, be excepted but of the ≈øaid Act as to life and e≈øtate.
They likewi≈øe ordered, that Hugh Peters and Cornet Joyce be forthwith ≈øent ≈øhe into cu≈øtody.

Re≈øolved, that the Hou≈øe doth declare that they do in the name of them≈øelves and the Commons of England, lay hold on his Maj ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es gracious pardon, mentioned in his former Declaration, with reference to the excepting of ≈øuch as ≈øhall be excepted in the Act of Pardon, and accordingly a Declaration was prepared and agree ‚Ä¢ unto‚ñ™ and a further Re≈øolve made that the Members of this Hou≈øe which are of his Maj ‚Ä¢ ≈øties Privy-Council, do acquaint his Maje≈øty with the Re≈øolves of the Hou≈øe, and de≈øire of his Maje≈øty that he would be plea≈øed to appoint when and where this Hou≈øe ≈øhall wait upon him.
The Hou≈øe took likewi≈øe into their con≈øideration the Bill for pre≈øerving the P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ viledges of Parliament, and confirming the Fundamental Laws, which was read and committed.

div.head: Friday, At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: Mr. Den ‚Ä¢ ill Holl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , a Member of the Hou≈øe, and one of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt honourable Privy-Councells, made a Report, that he had attended his Maje≈øty according to their Order, with the Re≈øolves of the Hou≈øe, declaring that they laid hold on his Maje≈øties gracious pardon mentioned in his former Declaration, and that his M ‚Ä¢ j ‚Ä¢ ≈øty had appointed to give them a meeting at three of the clock in the afternoon, at the banqueting hou≈øe.

The Committee that attended his Highne≈øs the Duke of Gloce≈ø≈øer, to give him the thanks of the Hou≈ø ‚Ä¢ for the affection he had expre≈ø≈øed in his Letter to them, reported, that the Duke did very kindly accept it, and a≈ø≈øured them of the continuance of his re≈øpect to them and that it ≈øhould be his ≈øtudy ≈øtill to declare it to them.
The Hou≈øe appointed a Committee to con≈øider of the Queens Joynture, and to con≈øider of a way to procure a pre≈øent ≈øupply for her Maje≈øty, and report the ≈øame.
The Hou≈øe ordered the Ordinance of A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment, and the Action putting in execution the powers in that Ordinance, to be forthwith printed and publi≈øhed.

They likewi≈øe ordered that all tho≈øe ≈øums of money that the City of London hath advanced upon that Ordinance, be forthwith paid out of ≈øuch money as ≈øhall be rai≈øed out of that A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment, and that the Chamberlain of London, who is Trea≈øurer, do ≈øoe the ≈øame paid accordingly.

Re≈øolved, that twenty; and no more, be≈øides ≈øuch as are already excepted, of ‚Ä¢ ite as Judges upon the Tryal of the late Kings Maje≈øty of ble≈ø≈øed memory, ≈øhall be excepted out of the general Act of pardon and ob ‚Ä¢ ivion, to ≈øuffer ≈øuch penalties or forfei ‚Ä¢ ures, not extending to life, as ≈øhall be thought fit to be inflicted on them by an Act to pa≈øs for that purpo≈øe.

div.head: Saturday.
div.p: Upon a report from the Committee of Priviledges and Elections, the Hou≈øe re≈øolved, that Mr. Secretary Morris, and Mr. Trelaw ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y, are duly elected, and ought to ≈øit as Members of Parliament for that Burrough.

Mr. Speaker informed the Hou≈øe, that Mr. William Heveningham, one of his late Maje≈øties Tryers, had rendered him≈øelf to him according to his Maje≈øties Proclamation, and that he put him into the hands of the Serjeant at Arms, till the further plea≈øure of the Hou≈øe was known concerning him; whereupon it was re≈øolved, that he ≈øtill remain in the cu≈øtody of the Se ‚Ä¢ jeant, till further order.

Upon reading the humble Petition of Adrian Scroop, it was ordered, That upon the payment of a years value of his e≈øtate, he ≈øhall not be excepted in the general Act of pardon, as to any part of his e≈øtate that is properly his o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and which he hath not purcha≈øed of, on doth belong unto the publick.

The Petition of Francis La≈ø≈øells was read, and it was re≈øolved, that he be di≈øcharged from being any longer a Member, uncapable of any office or place of publick tru≈øt, and that he pay one years value of his e≈øtate, upon payment whereof he ≈øhall not be excepted as to any part of his e≈øtate that is properly his own, &c.

The Petition of Colonel Hutchin≈øon, was read, expre≈ø≈øing much hearty ≈øorrow, and it was re≈øolved that he be di≈øcharged from being further a Member, uncapable of any office, and not to be excepted out of the Act of pardon.
Re≈øolved, that the Lord Grey of Groby be not excepted out of the Act of pardon:
Colonel Dove's Petition was read, and referred to a Committee.

The Petition of Sir Gilbert Pickering was read, and it was re≈øolved, that he ≈øhall be excepted, as to the penalties and forfeitures not te ‚Ä¢ ching to life, to be inflicted by an Act to be provided for that purpo≈øe; as al≈øo Thomas Challoner, James Chil ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or, Sir James Harrington, Lord Mon≈øon, John ‚Ä¢ ry, Tho. Li≈ø ‚Ä¢ er, Sir Henry Mildm ‚Ä¢ y, and Mr. John Phelps, Miles Corbet, John Okey, Robert Lilburn, Sir Mich. Live≈øey, Sir William Con≈øtable, Jr. Black≈øton, I≈øaac Penvington, Sir Tho. Malevorer, Sir Jeba Danvers, Sir Hardre≈øs Waller, VVilliam Goff, Edw. VVhaley, I≈øaac Ewers, Sir Jo. Bourchier, Edmund Ludlo ‚Ä¢ , VVilliam H ‚Ä¢ veningh ‚Ä¢ m, VVilliam Puref ‚Ä¢ y, Gilbert Millington, Henry Martin, Robert Tichb ‚Ä¢ , Richard Deane, John Carew, O ‚Ä¢ en Rowe, Colonel VValt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , James Temple, Peter Tem ‚Ä¢ le, French Allen, Daniel Blagrave, Thomas VV ‚Ä¢ ite, Simon Meyne, Tho. Andrews Alderman of London, Geo. Fleetwood, Augu≈øtine Garland, VVilliam Gawley, Tho. H ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ on, John Downes, Vincent Potter, Nich. Love, Jo. Dixwell, Tho. Hammond, Sir Gregory Norton, Percerine Pelham, Humphrey Edwards, Henry Smith, John Venus Edmund Harvey, Tho. VVogan, Jo. Al ‚Ä¢ ned _____ Moore and John Hew≈øon.
Re≈øolved, that the Serjeant at Arms do ≈øuch non Mr. Wallop to appear on Monday next.

THe Reader is to take notice that ≈øomthing was put into the la≈øt Publicus, concerning the entertainment of his Majesty at Roche≈øter, without the knowledge or privity of the Intelligencer, it being formerly otherwi≈øe repre≈øented by him.

div.head: Rome May 17.
div.p: The Popes Gallies are gone from Civittavecchia, with three of the Duke of Florence, for the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Venetians. The ≈øaid Duke hath given order for rai≈øing a Foot Regiment for Dalmatia, a great many Frenchmen, mo≈øt of tho≈øe that were pri≈øoners at Naples are li≈øting them≈øelves there, two hundred of them are arrived here.
The Queen Chri≈øtina of Swedeland is making ready to go about the beginning of the next month, to give ≈øome orders about her own Affairs, and is to return again hither.

Cardinal Grimaldi is arrived here, and lodged in the Palace Mazarin, Cardinal Mancini having yielded to him the be≈øt lodgings. They ≈øay he comes to ≈øpeak to the Pope of the bu≈øine≈øs of Comadico and Correggio, mentioned in the Forty two Article of the Peace, and that he brings the blew ribbon to the Duke of Bracciano from the King of France. The Cardinal Azolini and Pio, are ≈øaid to take the French party. The bu≈øine≈øs of the Carmelites is compo≈øed, the Pope having relea≈øed the Provincial of Provence.
Mr. Epidio Cardin ‚Ä¢ l Mazarines Agent, is gone to Naples to treat about ≈øome private bu≈øine≈øs with the Vice Roy.

div.head: St. John de Luz, June 1.
div.p: Y ‚Ä¢ ≈øterday at the fourth Conference, the two chief Mini≈øte ‚Ä¢ s ≈øigned the Treaty for regulating of the limits of Rou≈øillon, whereby the V ‚Ä¢ guery at Con≈øtans, the County of Carol, and 35 villages of Cerdagne are to remain to the French.

After the Conference, the Cardinal Mazarin gave a ≈øumptuous collation to Don Lewes D'Haro and his retinue, with a fine con≈øort of Voyces, and all kind of mu≈øical In≈øtruments, that played two hours together, during which, many French and Spani≈øh Songs were ≈øung, both ≈øtriveing
to ≈øhew their joy of the reunion of the two Crowns. Several Expre≈ø≈øes are ≈øent to cau≈øe the French Garri≈øons to go out of Ro≈øes, Cap de Quieres, Belver and Seau d'Urgel, and to put tho≈øe places in the hands of the Spaniards. Several Barks have been ≈øent from the harbor of Ayde to carry to that of Vendres in Languedoc, the Artillery, Ammunitions, and provi≈øions that are in tho≈øe places. The Regiment of Champagne that was in Ro≈øes, is commanded to go into the Bur ‚Ä¢ onois, tho≈øe of Harcourt, French Anjou, of the Galleys, Va ‚Ä¢ llac, E≈øti≈ø≈øac, Coign ‚Ä¢ c and Guienne to Perigueux, Sarlat and Bergerac. To morrow the King of Spain is expected at Fontarabia, where the next day the marriage is to be celebrated. The fourth the Duke of Crequi is to carry the Pre≈øents. The fifth the fir≈øt enterview is to be between the Queen and the King of Spain. The ≈øeventh the two Kings are to meet. The eighth the Infanta is to be delivered into the hands of the Queen her Aunt. The tenth the marriage is to be con≈øummated. The twelfth the Court is to go for Bordeaux, from whence the King is to go to Roch ‚Ä¢ l with the Cardinal, and meet the two Queens at Poitiers, to be together at Fontainebleau the fifteenth of July, where the promotion of the Knights of the order of the King is to be made.

div.head: Paris June 11.
div.p: Though by Letters from St. John de Luz, we have an account of the ≈øeveral days appointed for the Ceremonies of the Kings marriage, yet we hear not yet that any of them be accompli≈øhed, and the Marquis de Valavoir, who came from Court the third in≈øtant, ≈øuch that no day was yet certainly appointed for that. The Government of Champagne hath been be≈øtowed by the King on the Count of Soi≈ø≈øons; that of Bourbonois on the Moquis d'Humieres, and that of A ‚Ä¢ gue≈ømor ‚Ä¢ es on the Marquis of Var ‚Ä¢ es,
His Maje≈øty hath made a pre≈øent of 55000 crowns to the Marquis of Richelieu, which are to be put in the ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s of Moun≈øieur le ‚Ä¢ ellier, to ≈øee them well di≈øpo≈øed.

div.head: St. Seba≈øtian, the ≈øame date.
div.p: The 27 of the la≈øt month, the Infanta was above an hour upon a Belconi, in the Street where the Proce≈ø≈øion pa≈ø≈øed, and was ≈øeen there, with great ≈øatisfaction by all the French that were pre≈øent.
The King of Spain is to go to morrow with that Prince≈øs to Fontarabia, and from thence to the I≈øle, where the two Courts will meet.

div.head: Luxemburgh the ≈øame date.
div.p: The 25 of the la≈øt month there was a great fire at Arlon, which continued all the next day, and con≈øumed 240 hou≈øes, be≈øides the Pari≈øh Church, and the Covent of the Carmelits, but the fire was quenched by the re≈øolution of ≈øome Officers of the Gari≈øon, when it was come already within half a foot of the Powders, which would have ≈øpoiled the whole Town.

div.head: Pontoi≈øe June 10.
div.p: The fourth in≈øtant the general A≈ø≈øembly of the Clergy of France begun to ≈øit here, with the u≈øual Ceremonies in ≈øuch occa≈øion.

div.head:
Another from St. John de Luz,
June 2.
div.p:
The 27 of the la≈øt month, their M ‚Ä¢ je≈øties performed their Devotions at the Church of St. John, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted to the Proce≈ø≈øion with Mon≈øieur the Kings Brother, Madammoi≈øelle, and the two Prince≈ø≈øes her Si≈øters, the Bi≈øhop of Bayonne having officiated in the pre≈øence of many other Prelates. In the afternoon the King ≈øent the Marquis de Saucourt to complement the King of Spain and the Infanta, who received him very favorably. The 31. the Cardi ‚Ä¢ al Mazarin and Don Lewes D'Haro had a f ‚Ä¢ urth conference, where they happily ended the remaining difficulties, ≈øo that all is now ready for the Kings marriage, the King of Spain having ≈øent word, that without faile he will be to morrow at Fon ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ abi ‚Ä¢ , to ≈øee the fir≈øt ceremony celebrated there on the Thur≈øday following, and the next day after will repair to the I≈øle of the conference, where this court will be the fifth in≈øtant. After which the new Queen will be brought either for
the con≈øummation of the Solemnity, on the ≈øixth, in the Church of St. John, which is prepared for that end.

div.head: Stockholm, May 13.
div.p: This day the Corps of our late decea≈øed King arrived here, being accompanied by our young King, the Queen, and all the Senators and Grandees of the Kingdom, and was depo≈øited in the Cathedtal church, until all things be made ready for his funeral. Among other preparations that are making for the ≈øame, a Coffin all of ≈øilver curiou≈øly wrought, with the repre≈øentations of all the warlike exploits and atchievements of the ≈øaid King, is preparing, which will be worth above 6000 l. ≈øterling. The 4000 men lately levied here, have been lately mu≈øtered, and expect nothing but the orders for their march.

div.head: El≈øenore, May 15.
div.p: Since the taking of the ten Swedi≈øh ≈øhips by the Hollanders, the Mediators have not given any v ‚Ä¢ ≈øit to the Dutch Commi≈ø≈øioners, nor received any from them; and the≈øe ≈øeem to be ≈øomewhat perplexed how to palliate that affair. The ≈øaid Mediators have written a Letter to the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners about it, but received no an≈øwer upon it. They offered to carry the ≈øaid ≈øhips into a Dani≈øh harbor, to have them there adjudged lawful prize; but the King of Denmark hath hindred it, not being willing to meddle with that bu≈øine≈øs, which he doth not account to be ju≈øt. The Queen of Denmark hath given order for preparing a ≈øtately Banquet, where at ≈øhe intends to invite all the Mediators and Commi≈ø≈øioners, to have occa≈øion therein to reconcile the Dutch with the re≈øt of them.

div.head: Hague, Iune 11.
div.p: Prince Palatine Rupert came hither lately, thinking to have met here the King of England, but he was gone before, therefore he went back to his Quarters, having had leave to he ab≈øent only for Twelve days. The Prince≈øs Royal is going to Am≈øterdam with the Prince of Or ‚Ä¢ nge her Son, where they are to be gallantly entertained by the Magi≈øtrates of that place.

div.head: Adverti≈øements of Books newly Printed and Publi≈øhed.
div.p: ‚òûThe Hi≈øtory of His Sacred Maje≈øty, CHARLES the Second, King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, De ‚Ä¢ ender of the Faith, &c. begun from the horrible murder of his Royal Father of happy memory, and continued to this pre≈øent year 1660. Sold by Henry Ever≈øden at the Greyhound in S. Pauls Churchyard. The price, Eighteen pence.

The Charges i≈ø≈øuing forth of the Crown-Revenue of England, and Dominion of VVales. With the ≈øeveral Officers of His Maje≈øties Courts, Cu≈øtoms, Hou≈øholds, Hou≈øes, Ca≈øtles, Towns of War, Forts, Bulwarks, Forre≈øts, ‚Ä¢ arks, Cha≈øes, with their ≈øeveral Fees and A ‚Ä¢ lowances, according to the antient E≈øtabli≈øhment of the Kingdom. And al≈øo the valuation of he Bi≈øhops and Deans Lands, with the Tenths paid out of the ≈øame. By Captain Lazarus Haward. Sold by M. Wright at the ≈øign of the Kings Head in the Old-Baily.

div.head: An Adverti≈øement.
div.p: LO≈øt from Newbery, on Thur≈øday the 7 of June in≈øt. One Bay-Gelding about 15 hand high, all paces, a blemi≈øh on the near eye, and a ≈ømall gall on the near ≈øide of his back. One Black Nag, with the ≈øign of former Farcy on the far ≈øide and brea≈øt, and a little ≈øtar in the face, about 13 hand, only trot & gallop. One Bay-Mar ‚Ä¢ without white, about 12 hand, with a ≈øhort crooked no≈øe, trot and gallop. If any one can give notice where they are, or any two or one of them, to Mr. Tho. Gla≈øhrook at Brooks-wharf near Queen-Hithe, London, they ≈øh ‚Ä¢ ll have 20 s. for the three, or 10 s. If not all.

WHereas it is printed in a Book from the Office of Intelligence, that Luke Robin≈øon was di≈øcharged the Hou≈øe, for being one of the Judges of the late King. This is to inform. That he was none of the Judges, nor named in the Act for Tryal of the King.
A White Greyhound Bitch, belonging to his Excellency, was lately lo≈øt from the Cockpit. If any one bring her thither, he ≈øhall be well rewarded for his pains.

div.head: From the I≈øle of the Conference June 4. S. N.
div.p:
La≈øt Wedne≈øday the 2 In≈øtant about 7 a clock at night the King of Spain, with the Infanta and all the Grandees of his Court arived at Fon ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rabia, many Trumpets ≈øounding before hi ‚Ä¢ , and at the noy≈øe of all the Canon and the ≈øhot of the Mu≈øqueteers of that place, who gave fire above an houre together. In the mean time the ≈øaid King went into the Ca≈øtle of that Town, prepared before for his reception and hung with very rich Hangings, Till 9 of the clock his Maje≈øty and his Noblemen refre≈øhed them≈øelves, being extreamly weary of their long March, in a very rainy day. About that time his Maje≈øty called all his Grandees to him, and in their pre≈øence demanded of the Infant ‚Ä¢ her Renunciation to the Crown of Spain, which ≈øhe very willingly ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re under her hand, I know nothing of con≈øequence tran≈øacted there, be≈øides
that night. Ye≈øterday the 3 In≈øtant his Catholick Maje≈øty came to the Infanta's Lodgings to let her know that ≈øhe was to be married that day, de≈øiring her to be ready about eleven clock to goe wi ‚Ä¢ h him to the chief Church of that place. About one a clock in the afternoon the Bi≈øhop of Pampolune having been informed that the King of Spain was comming, took upon him Pontificall Habits, and the Cro≈ø≈øe and the Pa≈øtoral Hook being carryed before him, the Mu≈øick going before, he came to the Church doore, to receive his Maje≈øty, who at the ≈øame time alighting from his Co ‚Ä¢ ch, was conducted by the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop (the Infanta being at his left hand, both under a Canopy with Curtains on all ≈øides, but that which looked towards the Alter) The Ki ‚Ä¢ g and the Infanta were no ≈øooner upon their Knees, but the Bi≈øhop began a little or low Ma≈ø≈øe, which was very ≈øimple, very low and a very ≈øhort one, during which the Bi≈øhop of Frejus took his place by the Patriarch of the Indias, being bo ‚Ä¢ h re≈øpective witne≈ø≈øes for their re≈øpective Princes. The Ma≈ø≈øe ended, the Bi≈øhop put off his Prie≈øtly Garments and took on the Epi≈øcopal Robes, and coming down from the Alter, drew neere to the Canopy under which the King of Spain and the Infanta were; all this while Don Lewes D'Aro was behind the Canopy, but then coming near, and having made a very low obe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ence to the ≈øai ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ King and the Infanta, as Amba≈ø≈øador for the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, he pre≈øented to the Bi≈øhop the proxy he had of the ≈øaid King to marry the Infanta, which being read publickly and accepted of the Infanta f ‚Ä¢ ll to the King her Fathers feet, where after many reciprocal Tears for their near ≈øeparation: that Prince≈øs a≈ø≈øured him of her con≈øtant and perpetual ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, and demanded hi ‚Ä¢ Ble≈ø≈øing, which he gave her with many ki≈ø≈øes, which notwith≈øtanding his manly re≈øolution, drew again a flood of Tears from his eyes.

Then the ≈øaid Infanta having given her con≈øent to the mar ‚Ä¢ iage, as well as Don Lewes d'Aro, in the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Kings name, after the u≈øual words pronounced by the Bi≈øhop, the ≈øaid Don Lewis put on a rich ring upon the Infantas finger, and the re≈øt of the ceremonies being ended, the King of Spain looking how upon his Daughter as upon a Foreign Queen, gave her the right hand, and conducted her to the Coach. There was a co≈øtly Dinner prepared, the particulars hereof you may have fully hereafter, but I cannot omit what I hear for certain, that the King of France came there incognito, and was very much made of by the King of Spain, who a≈ø≈øured him of his re≈øolution for a perpetual peace and amity, for a token of which he gave him his Daughter, the preciou≈øe≈øt Jewel of his own eyes, and after their ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
tual Oaths for the performance of what they were agreed before, towards that peace and Amity, in ≈øuch a ≈øolemn manner as the like is not to be found recorded, the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King retired. Madamoi≈øelle was there al≈øo incognito, and very much made of, though no notice taken of her Quality.

This day, the Queen Mother, with Moun≈øieur the Kings Brother went to the Palace of the Conference, whether the King of Spain is to bring the Queen his Daughter, him≈øelf incognito. To morrow and the two next days, the two Courts are to meet again. The per≈øonal marriage is to be made, on Monday or Tue≈øday next, and Thur≈øday the whole Court is to return towards Paris. I mu≈øt not omit that the≈øe two days there will many ≈øeveral private vi≈øits between the two Kings and the Queens, be≈øides the publick „Äà‚óä„Äâ and that the new Queen will be brought hither on Monday next at night.
We have a particular accounts of all the Jewels be≈øtowed on the Infanta by the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King; being very con≈øiderable and large we mu≈øt ‚Ä¢ ea ‚Ä¢ e or the next.

div.head: Monday, June 11. at the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: It was re≈øolved, That Dr. Reynolds be de≈øired to carry on the work of Thank≈øgiving before this Hou≈øe on Thur≈øday come fortnight, the 28. of this in≈øtant Iune, (being a day ≈øet apart to return thanks to the Lord for his Maje≈øties ≈øafe return to his government and people) at S. Margarees VVe≈øtmin≈øter.

Re≈øolved, That the Lord General take care that the Oath of Supremacy and Allegiance be admini≈øtred to all the Officers and Soldiers of the Army. That the Lord High Admiral of England do take care that it be admini≈øtred to the Commanders and Mariners of the Fleet.
That his Maje≈øty be de≈øired to i≈ø≈øue forth a Proclamation, requiring all to take the Oath of Supremacy and Allegiance, that are enjoined by Law ≈øo to do.
The Hou≈øe rea≈ø≈øumed the debate of the Bill of Indempnity and Oblivion, and rea ‚Ä¢ the Letter of Robert VVallop E≈øquire; as al≈øo the humble Petition of Charls Lord St. Iohn.

Re≈øolved, that Robert VVallop be di≈øcharged from being a Member of this Hou≈øe, and une ‚Ä¢ , able of bearing any office of publick tru≈øt in the Nation; and that he be committed into the cu≈øtody of the Sergeant at Arms attending the Hou≈øe.
Re≈øolved, That Luke R ‚Ä¢ bin≈øon E≈øq be di≈øcharged from being a Member of this Hou≈øe.

R ‚Ä¢ ≈øolved, That Sir Henry Vane be one of the Twenty to be excepted out of the General Act ‚Ä¢ f Indempni ‚Ä¢ y and Oblivion, to ≈øuff ‚Ä¢ r ≈øuch pains, penalties and forfeatures (not extending to life) as ≈øhall be thought fit to be inflicted by an Act hereafter „Äà‚óä„Äâ be ma ‚Ä¢ e for that purpo≈øe.
Re≈ø ‚Ä¢ lved, That VVilliam Len ‚Ä¢ hal E≈øq be one of the Twenty to be excepted out of the General Act of ‚Ä¢ nde ‚Ä¢ nits and Ob ‚Ä¢ ivion, &c.
The Hou≈øe ordered now Writs ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øue for the election of Burge≈ø≈øes for the re≈øpective places following, viz.
A new Writ to i≈ø≈øue f ‚Ä¢ rth or the election of a Burg ‚Ä¢ ≈øs for Tiverton in com D ‚Ä¢ von. Mr. Bampfield having waved the election thereof, to ≈øerve for Exe ‚Ä¢ er.
A new Writ for a Burge≈øs to ≈øerve for VVhi ‚Ä¢ church in com. Southton. in the place of Robert Wallop E≈øq di≈øcharged from being a Member of this Hou≈øe.

Another for Nottingham
‚Ä¢ ow, in the place of Col. Iohn Hutchin≈øon di≈øcharg'd.
Another for North-Allerton, in the place of Francis ‚Ä¢ a≈ø≈øels di≈øcharged.
Re≈øolved, That the Bill for Sal ‚Ä¢ s be taken into con≈øideration on Friday next.
Re≈øolved, That the Bill for Mini≈øters be taken into con≈øideration on Saturday next.
The Bill for ‚Ä¢ oll-money was read the fir≈øt time.
The petition of ≈øeveral in ≈ølavery under the Turks, was read and referred to a Committee.

Re≈øolved, That the ≈øad condition of the Lord Inchequin and his Son now Captives under the Turk, he repre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nted to his ‚Ä¢ aje≈øty, and that his Maje≈øty be de≈øired that ≈øome effectual cour≈øe be taken for their redemption.

The Hou≈øe re≈øumed the debate upon the Bill of Indempn ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y and Oblivio ‚Ä¢ , and ordered „Äà‚óä„Äâ
William ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ion be one of the Twenty to be excepted, and to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pain ‚Ä¢ , penalties and forfeitures (not extending to life) as ≈øhall be thought fit to be inflicted on him by an act h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ enter to be made for that purpo≈øe‚ñ™
A Petition of Mr ‚Ä¢ . Love was read‚ñ™

div.head: Wedne≈øday, June 13. at the Hou≈øe of Lords.
div.p: Letters Patents from His mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty; con≈øtituting Sir Orlando Bridgman Lord Chief Baron of the Exchequer, Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Lords in the ab≈øence of the Lord Chancellor, were read and agreed unto; whereupon the Lord Chancellor going away, Sir Orlando performed that office.

div.head: At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p:
The Hou≈øe re≈øumed the Debate concerning the Bill of Indempnity and Oblivion, and Ordered that
Oliver St. John
Colonel Sydenham
Alderman Ireton
Colonel Disbrow
Sir Arthur He≈øilrigge
be of the Twenty to be excepted, &c.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p: On Monday May 11. the King of Swedens Plenipotentiories had a gracious Audience of His mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty.
On Tue≈øday ≈øeveral Swedi≈øh Lords waited on His Maje≈øty, and were graciou≈øly received.

The ≈øame day his Excellency pre≈øented an Addre≈øs from Col. Yaxley Robin≈øons Regiment to His Maje≈øty, which could not ≈øooner be ≈øent up, in regard that Regiment quarters about the farthe≈øt parts of Scotland, and is much di≈øper≈øed.
Col. Phaire, Col. Huncks Mr. Cook, and one Hulet, again≈øt whom evidence was given in Ireland, that he cut off His late Maje≈øties head, were according to Order brought pri≈øoners to town.

Sir William Salkeld was lately ≈øworne of the Gentlemen of the King Privy chamber in ordinary. And be≈øides the≈øe formerly mentioned, the Marquis of Hertford and General Montague received the honor of the mo≈øt Noble Order of the Garter.

The Lords ≈øent a me≈ø≈øage to the Commons, de≈øiring their concurrence to a Petitio ‚Ä¢ to be pre≈øented to His Maje≈øty from both Hou≈øes for publi≈øhing His Maje≈øties late Proclamation again≈øt debauched and prophane per≈øons, throughout the Kingdom, which the Commons agree unto

Mr. Speaker informing the Hou≈øe, that Mr Meyne, Col. Waite, and Col Temple, three of His late Maje≈øties Judges, had rendred them≈øelves to him according to the Proclamation, and that he had committed them to the Serjeant at Arms, the Hou≈øe approved of their commitment.
London, Printed by John Macock and Tho: Newcomb, 1660.
